Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Z-Threaded Carbon Fiber Composite Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to explore the opportunities of using a new technology to help manufacturers make carbon fiber composite products with higher production speed and lower cost. This novel fabrication technology produces materials that are stronger, stiffer, thinner, lighter, and better conductors of heat and electricity than current carbon fiber composites widely used in manufacturing industries. Parts produced from these new materials are more accurately made and have less internal stress remaining after manufacturing than previously. In addition, this technology will also reduce the energy consumption and material waste during the operation of vehicles and equipment that utilize them. Since carbon fiber composites are being increasingly used in many industries including aerospace, automotive, energy, marine, sporting goods, and defense, successful commercialization of the new technology catalyzed by this I-Corps project will bring significant benefits to the U.S. manufacturing base.

This I-Corps project is based on a new technology using long ultra-thin carbon nanofibers to thread through a bed of conventional thicker carbon fibers all surrounded by an epoxy resin adhesive. As a result, the thicker fibers are strongly bound together by the nanofibers, and all are held in place by the epoxy, to produce a composite material that is much stronger than either the epoxy resin alone or the conventional carbon fiber composite including the epoxy. This is called "z-threading". The network of interlocked carbon nanofibers and carbon fibers significantly improves the composite material's strength and conduction of heat and electricity. Conventional carbon fiber composite materials, typically in the form of a laminate, lack the z-threading nanofibers and have significantly poorer properties across the thickness direction of the laminate. As a result, manufacturing processes currently using carbon fiber composites will be significantly improved. This will allow production of more aggressively designed components with higher performance than has been possible before.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this I-Corps project is to use the I-Corps? market discovery method for investigating the potential fit of the team's technology, Carbon Nanofibers Z-Threaded Carbon Fiber Reinforced Plastics (i.e., ZT-CFRP), for various industries that utilize carbon fiber composites make their products. The originally expected industries to be investigated included automotive, aerospace, and wind energy.

Intellectual Merit: The ZT-CFRP technology utilizes long carbon nanofibers to thread through a bed of carbon fibers along the z-direction (i.e., the direction perpendicular to the carbon fiber bed surface), wherein each individual carbon nanofiber can effectively connect 10-50 carbon fibers (or even more depending on the length of carbon nanofibers) via mechanical interlock and polymer matrix adhesive. The network of interlocked carbon nanofibers z-threads and carbon fibers significantly improves the carbon fiber composite laminate's z-directional mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties. This novel technology allows the composite to be stronger, stiffer, thinner, lighter, more conductive for heat and electricity, while being produced with much shorter cycle time, better dimensional precision, and less residual stresses.  The I-Corps effort has helped the I-Corps team to find a niche initial customer segment for developing the product and received material donation and technical support from some new companies who could be potential partners. During the I-Corps? customer interactions, it was also found that each application and customer, in the market and technology competitiveness concerns, has a different set of needs in cost, production volume, and performance matric; the selection of acceptable resin system, resin additives, and carbon fiber type and fabric will affect the cost, production details? tuning, and performance matric and will be important consideration for commercialization of the ZT-CFRP or any multifunctional nanocomposites.    

Broader Impact: This I-Corps project activity provided the better development focus of the team to commercialize the ZT-CFRP technology and other related composites researches. Collaborations with two companies based on the mutual interests developed through the I-Corps project are ongoing, including several NDAs to form partnerships in several possible future projects.  In addition, the entrepreneur lead (EL) graduate research student, Sebastian Kirmse, was awarded second place ($3000 prize) in the 2018 Coastal Venture Competition hosted by the University of South Alabama Melton Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation (MCEI). One peer-reviewed journal paper, three peer-reviewed conference papers have been published. Two patents related to the I-Corps topics have been granted. Two Masters? theses are being written by the students (EL & co-EL). The EL student is continuing with his D.Sc. study, using systems engineering in commercialization of composite products with the PI.
